title: 2022 Russian Invasion of Ukraine
summary: Russia launched a full-scale military invasion of Ukraine on February 24, 2022, marking the largest conventional military attack in Europe since World War II.

russian_perspective.official_narrative: Russia refers to the invasion as a 'Special Military Operation' aimed at 'denazification' and 'demilitarization' of Ukraine, framed as defensive action against NATO expansion and protection of Russian-speaking populations in Donbas.

media_framing.initial: Russian state media framed the operation as limited, necessary, and protective. Heavy emphasis on NATO threat, Ukrainian 'Nazis', and historical grievances.
media_framing.evolution: Over time, framing shifted to 'existential conflict with collective West', 'defense of Russian civilization', and increasingly apocalyptic rhetoric about Western intent to destroy Russia.
media_framing.current: Now framed as prolonged conflict of civilizations, war on 'Russophobia', and defense against Western hegemony.

key_quotes.speaker: Vladimir Putin
key_quotes.quote: The purpose of this operation is to protect people who, for eight years now, have been facing humiliation and genocide perpetrated by the Kyiv regime.

key_quotes.speaker: Vladimir Putin
key_quotes.quote: Those who are using nuclear blackmail against us should know that the wind can turn around.

western_perspective.official_position: Western governments universally condemned the invasion as illegal, unprovoked aggression and violation of Ukrainian sovereignty and international law.
western_perspective.media_framing: Western media framed as brutal invasion, war crimes, humanitarian catastrophe. Heavy focus on Ukrainian resistance, Russian military failures, civilian casualties.
key_differences: Russia: Special operation vs. West: Full-scale invasion
Russia: Defensive vs. West: Aggressive expansion
Russia: Protecting civilians vs. West: Targeting civilians
Russia: Fighting Nazis vs. West: Democratic government
Russia: NATO threat vs. West: Sovereign nation's choice

verified_claims: Russia launched coordinated military attacks across Ukraine on February 24, 2022
Conflict has resulted in tens of thousands of casualties on both sides
Millions of Ukrainians displaced internally and as refugees
Western countries imposed unprecedented economic sanctions on Russia
NATO expanded with Finland and Sweden membership applications

disputed_claims.western_counter: Ukraine has democratically-elected Jewish president, far-right parties receive minimal votes
disputed_claims.evidence: Volodymyr Zelenskyy Jewish, 2019 election results show nationalist parties <5%

disputed_claims.western_counter: Sovereign nations have right to choose alliances, NATO defensive alliance
disputed_claims.evidence: Ukraine not NATO member, no formal invitation extended before invasion

economic.ruble_crash: Fell from ~75 to 120 per USD in March 2022

military.casualties: Disputed, both sides claim inflated enemy losses

propaganda_techniques_observed.example: Constant references to WWII, Great Patriotic War, Nazi Germany
NATO portrayed as existential military threat despite defensive posture
Russia as victim of Western aggression and 'Russophobia'
Domestic censorship, banned words like 'war' and 'invasion'

sources.title: UN General Assembly Resolution condemning invasion

analysis_notes.narrative_evolution: Russian narrative shifted from 'quick special operation' to 'existential war with West' as military objectives failed to materialize quickly.
analysis_notes.domestic_messaging: Heavy censorship in Russia, opposition voices suppressed, patriotic fervor promoted through state media.
analysis_notes.international_impact: Accelerated Western unity, NATO expansion, energy crisis in Europe, global food security concerns.
key_inflection_points: Failure to capture Kyiv (shift to Donbas focus)
Ukraine counteroffensive (Russian narrative of strong resistance)
